JayIRL 04-Dec-21 08:04 PM
I will collate the governance related stuff. Have asked for a governance channel as it goes beyond legal structure.
3
So specifically on legal structure. Med/Long term I think my proposal would be: Delaware LLC as the investment vehicle. Unincorporated association as the DAO vehicle. Have the UA as a member (legal term) of the LLC along with 2-5 other members voted in by the DAO. UA performs deal flow, risk and creates binding instructions on the legal member via votes or staking. The member is then obligated to take action on those instructions within the LLC. This way we decentralise the DAO, the decisionmaking and the deal flow. The LLC stands as the investment vehicle so fast moving advantage. Over time work out how to move away from the LLC model.
8
4
JayIRL
So specifically on legal structure. Med/Long term I think my proposal would be: Delaware LLC as the investment vehicle. Unincorporated association as the DAO vehicle. Have the UA as a member (legal term) of the LLC along with 2-5 other members voted in by the DAO. UA performs deal flow, risk and creates binding instructions on the legal member via votes or staking. The member is then obligated to take action on those instructions within the LLC. This way we decentralise the DAO, the decisionmaking and the deal flow. The LLC stands as the investment vehicle so fast moving advantage. Over time work out how to move away from the LLC model.

Template Legal Docs

jennifer hinkel 04-Dec-21 09:00 PM
Have been talking to a lot of corporate lawyers on this front re: setting up funds that are DAO-like/community governed, consensus right now is that due to lack of precedent or regulatory clarity, might need a 2-step process to get off ground, starting w/ a Series LLC structure as the longer-term aspects are ironed out
As far as state/jurisdiction selection, DE, NV, possibly WY, but there's a lot of debate about whether seeking a 501c3 status for the final form entity might bring a lot of tax benefit (which would then need to be a c-corp), so that's another angle to consider for the long term (e.g. requirements for Series LLC conversion to C Corp)
There are also two parallel legal/regulatory tracks that have to be considered: (1) The structure of "fund" or DAO entity itself and (2) legal treatment of the governance token/digital asset, the comments above are on (1) not (2)
jennifer hinkel

1
Inklin 05-Dec-21 11:49 PM
So a few ways this could work. Simple TradFi - Hyperscale acts [like] a fund and gives out USD 200k for 5% of a project/venture…. We all understand this model. Token based - Hyperscale holds $10m in reserve, gives out 100 tokens to each project in return for 5% of a project/venture. Crucially Hyperscale also promises to purchase each token for $2k, selling the token back to Hyperscale draws down the reserve and funds the projects… but the tokens can also be bought/sold/hodl by anyone. Maybe even listed somewhere? Pending legality. If one project succeeds the value of that project rises, the value of the 5% Hyperscale stake rises and the value of all tokens rises too. Every project benefits from the success of any single project as their stack of 100 tokens rises in value as it represent 5% ownership of all projects and is backstopped with the $10m fund to be drawn down. Investing then becomes self policing as each project only wants other successes projects in their Hyperscale round. It creates a virtuous circle, where projects are motivated to share resources and help each other succeed. If another project succeeds it increase the value of the tokens and increases the notional funding for all projects with the same token. (edited)
4

Inklin 06-Dec-21 01:09 AM
Lots of ways to explore, but the idea is that the token confers 2 things. 1). the right to redeem for cash. 2). If not redeemed the token represents a share of the equity of all the projects held by Hyperscale (edited)
3
If the token is not redeemed it acts like a share certificate in the community
So in theory the value of the token could rise above USD 2000, if some of the projects are successful
This then increases the available funding for the other projects automatically
And encourages everyone in the community to help each other and to collaborate
The tokens would be transferable so that projects can exchange them for cash, maybe with each other?? Maybe outside?
jennifer hinkel 06-Dec-21 01:11 AM
I like this framework a lot
I think the internal vs external one is very interesting
Inklin 06-Dec-21 01:12 AM
Also it means that approval into the community is self policing, projects want to work with good projects.
jennifer hinkel 06-Dec-21 01:12 AM
Maybe external only w certain other tokens/partners rather than a free for all? I don’t know if there’s added utility in having it traded speculatively, hmm
Inklin 06-Dec-21 01:12 AM
Well it has a floor price which is the value for which it can be redeemed
So $10m into a fund, less $1m for admin is $9m invested. That’s $200k for 45 projects. If each project gets 100 tokens on approval into the community then the face value of each token is $2000
If one of the projects takes off , the yet to be redeemed tokens will be worth more than $2000 as they represent equity in that project (edited)
So the tokens become a bit like a one way speculation, and that means you could probably sell them to outside speculators for more than their face value immediately after they are issued.
But that’s not really the point

Inklin 06-Dec-21 06:03 PM
This is an excellent point, tokenisation is more about operating securely at $100bn scale. At $200k approval size that would be 500,000 projects and 50,000,000 tokens. Deal size would probably change with volume. But at scale it’s likely 100,000’s daily transactions. Hence running it on a chain otherwise clearing overhead is significant. Securities law is a real challenge… for America. Not so most of the world, eg could easily run this model in London where markets are more laissez faire, although without addressing US securities law that would mean operating at the exclusion of US citizens. Something quite common for markets in London for exactly this reason. But V0.1 is likely an LLC sans tokens. (edited)

Setting this up to be a fully decentralized structure should not come at the cost of taking responsibility or developing trust with users—especially new users. Developing a compelling project that provides value to people should be the primary goal. In terms of the legal structure, it seems most effective to have Sam own and invest in the initial operation and then transition to the democratized version once we have a robust platform and secure way to ensure the transition occurs smoothly. If some people are concerned with Sam running away with the equity, then just have him agree to a legal statement that he will transition the platform to the democratized version in the future. I believe the legal structure and operational procedures should merely be a compliment to the larger goal of developing this to be robust on a technical level and trustworthy on a social level. I have experience with wealth management and securities law but that will be useless if this is built in a way that brings us into hot water. Very excited to see where this all goes, I’ve never seen a project get launched and grow this quickly.
JayIRL 07-Dec-21 06:34 PM
Fully agree, and at least so far the work has been very much in that direction. And personally I see 0 risk of Sam running off here.

fr3klz 08-Dec-21 08:27 PM
A month ago I devised a potentially novel concept to that could serve as a potential loop hole to get around investor accreditation issues.... If you follow the NFT space, you might remember last month a crypto punk was sold for over $500M. The person who owned the punk used a flash loan to buy and repay the loan over the course of a single transaction. Which now shows the punk sold for over $500M.... https://www.coindesk.com/tech/2021/10/29/heres-why-a-cryptopunk-sold-for-530m/ Which got me thinking... So what if a project issued NFTs to DAO members, used a flash loan to purchase the NFT for $5M each and set a lockup on the NFT. Now every member holding any NFT of such, should be able to qualify as a Qualified Purchaser as they hold asset(s) of $5M or more in value, which eliminates the 99 investor problem investor syndicates often run into. More info here -> https://feld.com/archives/2014/01/99-investor-problem.html To avoid potential unwanted tax exposure the NFT holder could burn the NFT by year end and re-issue a new one at the start of the next year, this way any potential gains are offset. (edited)

Inklin 10-Dec-21 12:36 AM
Any approval process that involves anonymous approvers is going to have some front running risk, as there is a risk that the application data is likely to be self doxxing. I believe there are 2 main ways to do approvals. 1). Assess ventures individually and decide y/n 2). Assess a batch, score, sort, cut, approve Pros and cons for each, 1) mints deals, 2) mints a mini portfolio Also you could have an application window where you invite the HS analysts, release e.g. 12 applications and try and assess a whole batch and approve/reject them in the space of a few hours. Thus minimising the window for front running. Is anyone gonna cut a deal within 2 hours of receiving a cold call from someone front-running HS? Nah. (edited)

How would a Delaware C Corp go about creating a DAO?

kevalin
How would a Delaware C Corp go about creating a DAO?
GeoCities 10-Dec-21 06:21 AM
Delaware law allows both corporations and LLCs to keep “records” on blockchain. When merging the idea of a DAO with a C-Corp, the first step is considering the corporate structure: Shareholders, Directors, and Officers. Shareholders are the owners and they elect the Directors. Directors can have various powers but their main function is electing the Officers. Officers are in day to day control of the corporation subject to powers/limitations defined by the articles/by-laws sometimes subject to vote by the Board. It may help to consider a C-Corp to automatically have multiple DAOs built-in, say a DAO for shareholders/BOD respectively. I think this concept can be merged with ENS domains and subdomains, with each subdomain wrapped into its own token as desired, for example: -corp.eth (the DE C-Corp) -shareholders.corp.eth (shareholder dao) -directors.corp.eth (BOD dao) Selling tokens for the shareholders.corp.eth DAO would almost inevitably run into securities issues unless structured to fit an exception to registration. One idea to circumvent this could be an airdrop of shareholder.corp.eth tokens. Directors.corp.eth DAO tokens that are limited to governance/voting rights are very likely the easiest to sell while minimizing any risk of securities issues. Unlike a traditional C-Corp where shareholders elect directors, the directors could be unelected and include all that hold a directors.corp.eth DAO token. The idea of a Directors DAO electing Officers that generally have day to day control of corp.eth subject to Director control/votes over budget is very likely the most effective, especially in these early days of DAO operations. People might push back against the “boomerness” of this type of structure and prefer an LLC over C-Corp where instead of 3 levels to the organization there are 2: members(owners)/managers. More practically the LLC also has less compliance formalities. (edited)
4

GeoCities 10-Dec-21 06:34 PM
I read through, it’s very good, but one of the problems in law is that this 30 page paper is in fact a summary/overview of law The paper is light on examples, where HS presents a specific set of facts to apply the law. Ill pro-offer the following examples that serve as potential domestic models (non-DAOs) consistent with the paper and an existing off-shore DAO model: 1. The Green Bay Packers, Inc., a Wisconsin Non-profit Stock Company. The only not for profit NFL team, every 10 years or so they raise funds by publicly issuing “stock” to fund the team operations. Every public offering they obtain a no-action letter from the SEC so there is an existing legal framework, just replace their “stock” with governance tokens. 2. Erica Enders Racing, LLC, a Texas LLC. Very similar to Green Bay Packers, except a for profit LLC, the Enders race team raises funds through a public offering of LLC Membership. Similarly the team obtains no-action letters from the SEC so again there is legal precedent. 3. The ENS Foundation, a Caymen Islands Exempted Limited Guarantee Foundation Company (“non-profit”). Uniquely structured compared to GB Packers where the DAO is essentially a made up council within the Foundation, often called committees within US entities. Perhaps the most interesting/beneficial from the tax perspective. The respective Articles are all available, as well as the SEC no-action letter requests/SEC responses. If anyone would like to take a deep dive I can provide links to the same.

GeoCities 10-Dec-21 06:43 PM
They are not, the publicly offered membership (what’s sold to fans) fall into a non-voting, non-managing class of membership certificates (let’s call it Class B”). I believe Erica and her father are the only Members of what we can call Class A and are entitled to distributions. That said this model can be modified consistent with other suggestions in this channel where the DAO token holders instead of being LLC Members (“owners”) will collectively be the LLC Managers and the funds would flow to the token holders as “management fees” instead of to the Members as distributions. (edited)

Qworg 10-Dec-21 06:49 PM
There's a limit on LLC managers per entity, right? I suppose you can stack up LLCs... Thanks @GeoCities
Qworg
There's a limit on LLC managers per entity, right? I suppose you can stack up LLCs... Thanks @GeoCities
GeoCities 10-Dec-21 06:56 PM
It’s a state issue. Under the Delaware Limited Liability Company Act a manager managed LLC must have at least 1 manager, but I’m not aware of an upper limit. Also they may make contributions and share in the distributions. Under the new Wyoming DAO LLC law a DAO LLC maybe be “algorithmically managed.” Though brand new and untested, I understand being managed by the collective token holders is the specific intent of the new law.

GeoCities 13-Dec-21 11:54 PM
Referencing reverse mergers/reverse IPOs in general. Often the public companies this happens with are penny stocks/pink sheets. Nothing inherently wrong with that, but there are sometimes issues of ongoing liabilities/litigation or shareholders that carry over. Even non-public entities with history that might include prior conversions/domestications (ie changing entity structure like LLC to C-Corp., changing States, etc…) can give investors/lawyers concerns. Again nothing wrong with it, it just presents potential risk that can be minimized with an entity with no history.

Brennen Hodge | Citizen DAO 14-Dec-21 03:05 AM
But... I think there is a new legal structure that no one is using for this purpose -- a Public Benefit Limited Cooperative Association in Colorado. That's a mouthful, but it is a new formation in the past decade. The LCA is the traditional cooperative model with an added section to include investors.
Here's some info on LCAs: https://jrwiener.com/limited-cooperative-associations-and-early-stage-financing/ Jason Wiener is the lawyer we would need to talk to as he's the leader in this space.

Cooperatives are the original social enterprise business model and Colorado is emerging as the “Delaware of cooperative law,” thanks in no small part to limited cooperative associations (LCAs), authorized by C.R.S. Title 7, Article 58. The limited cooperative association is a relatively new entity type, adopted in Colorado in 2010.  It offers a ...

pricel3ss 14-Dec-21 03:14 AM
These securities laws generally make it illegal to sell loans or shares to members in a broad offering, even to a community or members of a co-op, unless state or federal securities registration is filed (which is usually much too expensive and detailed to be practical) or there is an exemption from this registration requirement. Consequently, exemption from securities registration for co-op member loans and preferred shares is key. Most of the co-op member investment programs use a combination of the SEC “intrastate exemption” and a state-specific exemption for securities sold to cooperative members. The intrastate exemption precludes SEC jurisdiction if the program is limited to residents of a single state (there cannot be even one non-resident member investor) and the co-op is doing business in the state. The SEC rules say that: (i) the co-op must have derived 80 percent of its gross revenues from within the state in the past six months; (ii) 80 percent of the co-op’s assets must be located in the state; (iii) 80 percent of the proceeds of the offering must be used within the state; and (iv) the principal office of the co-op must be located in the state
^is there a way around that part lol?

Griz 16-Dec-21 11:49 PM
I’m interpreting this statement to mean that each of the smaller entities would invest in a particular niche. I’d expect that to be a concern from a diversification perspective. Investors need exposure to a portfolio of these bets to try and increase the probability that they have exposure to the rare outlier returns. When I checked last, YC's top 3 startups account for roughly half of the combined enterprise value of all ~3,000 startups that they’ve backed. Sharding these bets by industry changes the expected value calculation and increases variance for investors that only have exposure to a small subset of the startups.

Inklin
So a few ways this could work. Simple TradFi - Hyperscale acts [like] a fund and gives out USD 200k for 5% of a project/venture…. We all understand this model. Token based - Hyperscale holds $10m in reserve, gives out 100 tokens to each project in return for 5% of a project/venture. Crucially Hyperscale also promises to purchase each token for $2k, selling the token back to Hyperscale draws down the reserve and funds the projects… but the tokens can also be bought/sold/hodl by anyone. Maybe even listed somewhere? Pending legality. If one project succeeds the value of that project rises, the value of the 5% Hyperscale stake rises and the value of all tokens rises too. Every project benefits from the success of any single project as their stack of 100 tokens rises in value as it represent 5% ownership of all projects and is backstopped with the $10m fund to be drawn down. Investing then becomes self policing as each project only wants other successes projects in their Hyperscale round. It creates a virtuous circle, where projects are motivated to share resources and help each other succeed. If another project succeeds it increase the value of the tokens and increases the notional funding for all projects with the same token. (edited)

Qworg 22-Dec-21 09:30 PM
I also love this proposal - there's some work to be done to firm it up, but it aligns with how I think about this. Per QV: that relates more to voting/decision making. For example, if there was a second class of tokens (HypeVote or $HV), those could be used to make investment decisions on a round basis. Your total $HV is awarded per round (no carryover) and you get a stack of them based on your $HYPE holdings (logrithmic?). Voting with $HV is quadratic - so 1 vote costs 1 $HV, 2 costs 4 $HV, 3 costs 9 $HV - and the benefits of the vote accrue based on conviction (how many votes you put into any winner).
Heck, we could really juice @Inklin 's proposal with a double OHM system.

I know tokenomics are not important for MVP, but curious. When we get returns from an investment (for instance if we sell our 5%), where should this money go? One thought is to put this money back into our reserve and proportionally increase how much money can be redeemed when someone wants to cash in their HYPE token. The thinking here is that now our token is not rising because of speculation but from how the actual fund is doing. Did you have other thoughts on how this might work? (edited)
kevalin 26-Dec-21 01:12 AM
I'm thinking of implementing some sort of rebasing mechanism. HYPE would be pegged to 1 USDC. If the price of HYPE > 1 USDC then HYPE is printed and dumped into the HYPE/USDC pool. If the price is below the HYPE treasury sells USDC for HYPE. This will allow the protocol to control monetary policy through rebasing. Rebasing siphons from speculators to long-term stakers and the ecosystem projects. Ecosystem projects & community members (long-term stakers) will get a percentage of the positive rebase.
1
As the treasury grows (through returns) more HYPE is printed and given to stakers. This is how we'll capture speculative value. A good mental model for how this works is YAM + OHM. (edited)
There'll also be a rage-quit function where people can redeem HYPE for treasury assets directly

kevalin 26-Dec-21 01:53 AM
Really like the idea of detaching voting power and $HYPE holdings. Rewarding $HV on a log basis makes a ton of sense. But it would be redundant if voting w/ $HV is quadratic. Detaching voting power and $HYPE holdings will also encourage $HV delegation.
If Charlie had 100 $HYPE he'd get 50 $HV; if Alice and Bob held a combined 100 $HYPE they'd get a combined 60 $HV. If Bob delegated $HV to Alice they'd have more combined voting power.
The best capital allocators would naturally get the most voting power. People would have an incentive to delegate voting power. This benefits both $HYPE holders and capital allocators. Rewards based on conviction should be paid out pro rata to how much $HV you vote with. This would be the case if $HV voting isn't quadratic (which I don't think it should). Why do you say that $HV should be awarded per round with no carry over? Also I like the idea of clear rounds to start. We'd then decrease the round interval as the investment process is refined. (edited)

To answer a few questions - I agree that the log distribution of $HV AND quadratic voting is probably too much. Best allocators get voting power, as long as $HV is awarded on merit as well. Multivoting without QV is an interesting idea, I agree that with a log limit it gives the properties you're describing. Per $HV awarded per round, no carryover - each "round" of DAO race or voting should provide $HYPE holders a set amount of $HV for that round only - you can't bank $HV round to round. This pushes allocators/voters into the pool.

Griz 26-Dec-21 06:26 AM
I like the idea of trying to leverage a market mechanism to facilitate discovery of strong capital allocators. I’m wondering whether the people that look like the best capital allocators in the short run turn out to be the best capital allocators in the long run. For example, Bob casts the first vote in the entity that wins the DAO race 5 out of 10 weeks in a row. Alice casts the first vote in the entity that wins the DAO race 1 out of 10 weeks in a row. But, because of the power law distribution of winners here, Alice’s pick ends up being worth far more than all 5 of Bob’s combined. The problem is that, for many people, Bob will appear to be the better capital allocator until years later when it becomes clear that Alice’s pick was the giant winner in the bunch. And, this gets even messier when you consider that the best early stage capital allocators often (i) are independent thinkers, (ii) make picks that often look like bad ideas initially, (iii) make non-obvious picks because they understand something others don't, and (iv) have skin in the game. This is Google’s original logo: https://miro.medium.com/max/731/1*sYFdd2izrxgjSXwujnOd9A.jpeg (edited)

GeoCities 26-Dec-21 10:37 AM
Very interesting. As I read this I am reminded of the decentralized DeFi platform Sushi. $Shush is a token of value that is traded. $Shushi can also be staked for the governance token ($ShushiX) , but $ShushiX also receives distributions paid in $Sushi from the fees generated by the DeFi platform. It is a proven mechanism for encouraging long-term support not just speculation on token value. If I understand correctly: $HYPE would be the value token (and what is used to make investments in DAOs and pay out rewards/incentives). $HYPE can be staked by delegating to capital allocators (“delegates”) who vote with the staked $HYPE as $HV. Unlike $SushiX which pays the platform fees in $Sushi as a proportion of the % of $ShushiX held, $HYPE would be paid in proportion to some measure of delegator performance. One potential concern, by shifting the incentive away from directly rewarding an individual for their personal votes to rewarding based on the voting of the delegate staked, this may raise Howey concerns. (edited)

Although I think the economics of the power law is upstream from legal here, the more fundamental legal issue lurking in the background is whether voting on funding decisions in exchange for compensation makes voters investment advisors that need to be registered. This is an issue regardless of whether votes are delegated or not. https://www.sec.gov/about/offices/oia/oia_investman/rplaze-042012.pdf (edited)

joshpizzaro

Griz 26-Dec-21 09:11 PM
Nope. Accreditation is mainly an issue for who can invest in certain types of securities offerings. Worth noting that recently the SEC drastically reduced the bar for who counts as accredited. In the current US system, the form that a security takes doesn't impact which regulations apply. Doesn't matter if the security takes the form of a stone tablet, paper contract, or security token. The same regs apply. But, the Coinbase Digital Asset Policy Proposal shows a different path forward.
Ryu
TSLA doesn’t make any attempt to peg to something tho. I’m still antsy about the notion of a peg. If you really tried to peg, you’re open to a host of potential problems (for example, BTC is basically a store of value against depreciating fiat, so your basis (USD) is depreciating at some unknown rate, and of course there’s the rather centralized operators of USDC etc.)
David Seto, Esq. davidseto.eth 27-Dec-21 02:32 AM
One thing with a peg is stablecoins will come under banking regulations eventually. If a peg it’s a bank instrument if no peg it could be a security and come under securities regs. I would prefer coming under securities rules because more well known and exemptions available better understood.

Griz 27-Dec-21 02:53 AM
Last month Treasury issued a report on stablecoins that stated, “…legislation should limit stablecoin issuance, and related activities of redemption and maintenance of reserve assets, to entities that are insured depository institutions. The legislation would prohibit other entities from issuing payment stablecoins.” Unclear if a token redeemable for a fixed quantity of stablecoin would itself be considered a stablecoin. If Treasury gets what it wants, stablecoin will be defined broadly. Today, if the stablecoin is redeemable for currency, the issuer of the stablecoin would likely have to register with FinCEN as a money service business and seek licenses from the various state money transmitter regulators as a payment instrument issuer. (edited)

Griz 27-Dec-21 07:02 AM
The full analysis requires more information than we have at this time. Check out page 11 here for an example of the analysis of Libra: https://financialservices.house.gov/uploadedfiles/hhrg-116-ba00-wstate-brummerc-20190717.pdf. Your intuition is totally right, though. Some stablecoins may be securities. It largely depends on how the peg works exactly. Do people intervene to maintain the peg and is it pegged against a basket of assets? Or is it simply a monetary equivalent? But, note, as @GeoCities pointed out earlier, something can be a security at T0 and not a security at T10 or vice versa. (edited)
Inklin 27-Dec-21 10:10 AM
Unpopular observation: Almost every decision is compromised by the choice of US jurisdiction. If you built the best technical version of Hyperacale and also built the US security and investment law compliant version. How do you think they would compete over 10 years? Because someone is gonna build the international technically uncompromised version. You can build entire token economies, people can anonymously earn an income in tokens and then draw their funds into irl via crypto markets. Isn’t there a risk that in the future, web3 escapes legal jurisdiction? Obviously we should comply with the law and our community is majority US based. But it’s a very real risk that someone builds a version that ignores US laws and just excludes US citizens, the majority of the worlds financial products are built to exclude US citizens. The effect is that it splits the market.
2
Not suggesting we change anything, just that we have our eyes wide open to this.

kevalin
Really like the idea of detaching voting power and $HYPE holdings. Rewarding $HV on a log basis makes a ton of sense. But it would be redundant if voting w/ $HV is quadratic. Detaching voting power and $HYPE holdings will also encourage $HV delegation.
If Charlie had 100 $HYPE he'd get 50 $HV; if Alice and Bob held a combined 100 $HYPE they'd get a combined 60 $HV. If Bob delegated $HV to Alice they'd have more combined voting power.
The best capital allocators would naturally get the most voting power. People would have an incentive to delegate voting power. This benefits both $HYPE holders and capital allocators. Rewards based on conviction should be paid out pro rata to how much $HV you vote with. This would be the case if $HV voting isn't quadratic (which I don't think it should). Why do you say that $HV should be awarded per round with no carry over? Also I like the idea of clear rounds to start. We'd then decrease the round interval as the investment process is refined. (edited)

aceee 05-Jan-22 04:38 AM
Option #5: Combinations So far, the most common approach I’ve seen is actually to mix and match. Typically this means creating a Foundation that is the official legal wrapper of the “DAO” and a separate, wholly unrelated, “Development Agency” (DA) onshore somewhere. This DA is incorporated as an LLC or local equivalent and is registered as a normal non-crypto entity. A common path is the Cayman Foundation + a Singapore entity. Singapore is often chosen because of it’s relatively low tax rate (~17%), business-friendly regulation, and ease of set up for non-Singaporean residents. Here’s how it works: the DAO has the treasury. Typically, the treasury is held in a multi-sig wallet that “belongs” to the DAO. The DAO/Foundation should also have a business account with an exchange like FTX to provide a fiat off-ramp should you need to pay lawyers, accountants, etc in meatspace. The DA pays the leadership team and all associated expenses for the DAO. The Foundation has a Service agreement with the DA and pays accordingly. If, for example, there were $100,000 in expenses, the Foundation may send $120,000 to the DA. The DA then pays taxes on the $20k of profit, ensuring that you are paying taxes somewhere as mentioned at the beginning of this essay. In this fashion, the dual structure seems to provide the ideal balance of Legal Liability and Tax Protection.

Typically this means creating a Foundation that is the official legal wrapper of the “DAO” and a separate, wholly unrelated, “Development Agency” (DA) onshore somewhere. The DA pays the leadership team and all associated expenses for the DAO. The Foundation has a Service agreement with the DA and pays accordingly. If, for example, there were $100,000 in expenses, the Foundation may send $120,000 to the DA. The DA then pays taxes on the $20k of profit, ensuring that you are paying taxes somewhere as mentioned at the beginning of this essay. In this fashion, the dual structure seems to provide the ideal balance of Legal Liability and Tax Protection.
